title: 1963 Fanfare for the Common Men
author: Eddie Robson
filename: 178 - 1963 Fanfare for the Common Men - Eddie Robson_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
WHO THEME
SCENE 1. INT. APARTMENT — 1970
F/X NEW YORK CITY TRAFFIC NOISE OUTSIDE WINDOW. MARK (30 AT
POINT, LIVERPUDLIAN, SARDONIC) IS BEING INTERVIEWED.

The thing is, because we were in the middle of it all, to us it never felt real, you know? I sometimes wonder whether it ever was. (BEAT) But I think we properly realised what was happening when we came back from the tour in Sweden. First time we’d played abroad since we’d had a hit, and the second our plane landed back in London it was like —
SCENE 2. EXT. LONDON AIRPORT — 1963
F/X HUGE, SHRILL, TEENAGE CHEER. WE HEAR ODD SHOUTS LIKE ‘IT’S
THEM!’ ‘WE WANT THE BOYS!’ ‘I CAN’T BELIEVE IT!’ BUT MOSTLY IT’S INAUDIBLE. DOCTOR AND NYSSA MUST SHOUT TO BE HEARD.
This is what I was talking about, Nyssa.
Why is everyone making so much noise, Doctor? We can’t even see them yet.
Just to be in the same place as them is exciting enough.
So will they play music when they get off the plane?
No.
What will they do?
Walk through the airport, get into a car and go home, I expect.
So all these people are just here to shout at them?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 2
Yes, essentially. This is what the Beatles inspired in people.
Just for playing music?
And writing music. And for just being Beatles. Shall we see if
we can get a closer look?
Will it be louder there?
Probably about the same, I should
What?
Probably about the same.
Oh. All right then.
SCENE 3. INT. PLANE — 1963
F/X THE COMMON MEN — MARK, JAMES
DISEMBARK.
They can’t be here for us.
They’ve got banners with the name
They’re not telling us to go back
think.
AND KORKY — ARE WAITING TO
of the group on.
where we belong, are they?
I don’t think we could if we wanted to. They say you can never go home again, don’t they? We’re in another world now, boys.
Another world.
F/X THE PLANE DOOR OPENS, HE STEPS OUT. THE CROWD CHEERS
LOUDER.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 3
SCENE 4. INT. AIRPORT — 1963
F/X IN THE CROWD; STILL LOTS OF NOISE, BUT NOW WE CAN JUST
OUT ‘I LOVE YOU, JAMES!’ ‘MARRY ME, MARK!’ ‘KORKY! OVER HERE!’. DOCTOR AND NYSSA TRYING TO GET A GOOD VIEW.
I can’t see a thing.
I can, just about... yes — there they are! John, Paul, George and... oh.
What is it?
Why are there only three of them?
Cos there are only three of them, granddad.
Only three Beatles?
Who are the Beatles?
That’s who everyone’s here to see. Isn’t it?
Don’t be daft. There’s only one group going to get a crowd like this. The Common Men.
The who?
No, they don’t get together until next year. (TO RITA) The Common Men? They do sound familiar...
Of course they do. Mark, James and Korky. Look — they’re coming this way! Oh my god, they’re coming this way!
(BEAT) Good grief.
What is it, Doctor?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 4
It’s not them.
Who are these Beatles then? Are they another group?
Yes.
Are they any good?
Well... they were...
Nobody’s as good as The Common Men. (SHOUTS) Boys! Over here!
You haven’t landed us in the wrong place, have you, Doctor?
No. 31°* October 1963 — this is definitely right. Something is very, very badly... Oh no!
What? What are you looking at?
(SHOUTS) Get down! Over there — he’s got a gun!
F/X IMMEDIATE CROWD REACTS — ‘WHAT?’ ‘WHO’S GOT A GUN?’
‘WHAT’S HAPPENING?’ — BUT THE REST OF THE CROWD DROWNS HIM OUT.
What?
(SHOUTS) The man in the brown coat! He’s got a gun!
He’s moving through the crowd. (MOVING OFF) I’1l get him.
Nyssa — no!
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 5
SCENE 5. INT. AIRPORT — 1963
F/X WITH THE COMMON MEN, GOING PAST THE CROWD — MOST OF WHOM
STILL IN COMMONMANTIA MODE.
Did someone say something?
Everyone said something, Korky. That’s why it’s so noisy in here.
(OFF) There’s a man in the crowd with a gun!
A gun?
Gun?
He said there was a gun.
Get down!
F/X TWO LASER-GUN ZAPS WHIZZ ABOVE THEIR HEADS AND HIT GLASS,
IT TO SHATTER AND FALL. TERROR IN CROWD.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 6
SCENE 6. INT. AIRPORT — 1963
F/X IN THE CROWD. PANIC — ‘OH MY GOD!’ ‘GET AWAY!’ ‘HE’S GOING
TO KILL THEM!’.
(TO HERSELF) There you... are!
F/X NYSSA DIVES AT THE GUNMAN (LENNY), KNOCKS HIM TO THE FLOOR.
Oof!
(STRUGGLING) Got you!
(OFF) Well done, Nyssa! Hang on to him!
I can’t hold him down forever — someone grab his gun!
F/X LENNY OPERATES A DEMATERIALISATION DEVICE AND NYSSA’S NEXT
FADES...
Quickly, before he tries [again]!
F/X AND THEY’RE GONE. CROWD AROUND THEM GASPS, BAFFLED —
‘WHAT?’ ‘WHERE DID HE GO?’ ‘AM I SEEING THINGS?’.
(OFF) Nyssa? Nyssa!
F/X DOCTOR AND RITA RUN OVER.
Oh no.
Where’d she go? Both of them, they just.. (BREAKS OFF) Where did they go?
I’ve no idea.
F/X JAMES DASHES OVER.
What happened to him: the loony with the gun?
He got away. I’m sorry.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 7
As long as everyone’s all right... you’re the one who shouted?
Yes, I saw him in the crowd, he pulled a gun...
He just vanished...
Funny noise his gun made.
Yes, funny. I’m afraid I only saw him from behind — I didn’t get a good look at his face.
Nice to meet you, anyway. I’m James.
Yes, I know.
I’m the Doctor, and this is...
Um. Er. Rita.
Me and the boys’d like to say thanks — can we buy you a drink?
There’s really no — (BEAT) Actually yes.
F/X JAMES KEEPS TALKING AS HE WALKS AWAY.
Great. Come on by the bar in the First Class lounge. (BEGINS
OFF; CALLS BACK) Bring your girlfriend too, if you like.
(CALLS) I’m not his girlfriend. (TO DOCTOR) D’you think he heard that?
I’ll happily set him straight, if it matters to you.
F/X THE CROWD IS MOVING ON AROUND THEM.
Sorry. Not a big deal, is it, after what happened to your friend.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 8
I have to find her.
I did see what I thought I saw, didn’t I?
Yes.
She just faded out like she was never here. Was she a ghost?
No, she accidentally piggy-backed onto a matter dematerialisation device.
(BEAT) OK.

Looked like it was fourth-dimensional, and it must’ve been small enough to wear under his coat so he can’t have travelled that far.. which narrows it down to anywhere on this planet within a temporal radius of a decade or two. Wonderful.
I’m not sure if I’m still recovering from the shock or if you’re just talking gibberish.
Simple version: the gunman escaped somewhere in time and Nyssa’s been dragged along with him.
Right.
It must have something to do with the change in history — so going for a drink with the three men at the centre of that change seems as good a place as any to start.
You think they know who that guy was?
I assume he's not a friend, since he was firing an impulse laser at them, but we’1ll see what we can find out.
We? You mean you and me?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 9
It might be useful to have someone along who knows about them. If you don’t mind.
What kind of idiot would mind meeting the Common Men?
SCENE 7. EXT. DOCKS — 1960
F/X HAMBURG. THE TIME MACHINE LENNY USED IN 1963 BRINGS HIM
AND NYSSA HERE. THE NOISE OF THE TIME MACHINE SOUNDS UNSTEADY, UNHEALTHY.
(COMPLETING HER SENTENCE AS THEY MATERIALIZE) [Before he tries] again. Oof!
F/X THE TWO OF THEM LAND HEAVILY ON THE GROUND, AS IF DROPPED
FROM A COUPLE OF FEET IN THE AIR. WINDED, LENNY STRUGGLES TO GET TO HIS FEET.
Get off me, you stupid-!
(CLINGING TO HIM) Not until you tell me who you are — and where we are!
F/X FROM A DISTANCE, KORKY SHOUTS AT THEM.
(OFF) Hey! What’re you doing with that lass?
Damn!
F/X LENNY RUNS, SHOVING NYSSA TO THE GROUND. KORKY RUNS OVER
TO HER.
You all right, love?
I.. I think so.
(CALLS) Give us a hand, boys!
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 10
F/X MARK AND JAMES DASH OVER.
Damsel in distress, is it Korks?
Usually your department, James.
I know. I’m envious.
Help me get her up.
Oh, now he wants help, but you see if he wants help with her later.
Come on, let’s get the poor girl off the deck.
F/X THE THREE OF THEM HELP NYSSA UP.
Thank you. You’re very kind.
So what’s a posh girl like you doing down the docks at midnight?
Give over, Mark. (TO NYSSA) Did you know that bloke, luv?
No.
Just some creepy kraut, then.
Kraut?
You know, kraut. German.
What made you think he was German?
(LOUD AND SLOW) Because you’re in Germany, love.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page I1
She must’ve got bopped on the head. (TO NYSSA) Where are you staying? We’ll help you back.
I don’t know.
We should take her back to the digs. Sit her down where it’s warm.
We’re back onstage in fifteen minutes.
We’ve got time. She needs a cup of tea.
We haven’t got a kettle.
Or any tea.
I’m fine, thank you. (BEAT) You’re the group from the airport.
You’ve got us confused with someone else. We’ve never been to an airport in our lives.
We took the boat train.
Come on. Come back with us.
Korky!
We’ll make the gig! And if we don’t, we’ll get The Beatles to cover for us.
Beatles. I came to see the Beatles.
Then you’ve had a wasted trip. It’s their night off tonight. Come on.
F/X THEY SHUFFLE OFF WITH NYSSA.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 8. INT. APARTMENT — 1970
F/X AS BEFORE.

When we dragged her back to our place, she asked what year it was. I never thought it at the time, but obviously now I realise she was on something. You could probably get it back then if you were posh and knew the right people. But she was alright. Korky liked her a lot. (BEAT) I wonder what happened to her?
SCENE 9. INT. AIRPORT LOUNGE — 1963
F/X CALMER IN HERE, NOBODY MAKING A FUSS OF THE GROUP. VERY
CHAT MURMUR, NOTHING AUDIBLE. PLANES TAKING OFF IN BACKGROUND.
I’ve never been on a plane.
I’m not getting on one any time soon. Not after what happened last time.
What’re you drinking, Doctor?
Just a ginger ale for me, thank you Jo[hn]- um, Mark.
And for you, Rita?
Gin and tonic.
I’ll bring those over for you, sir.
F/X WAITER GOES TO GET THE DRINKS.
Still can’t get used to all this VIP treatment.
I think I could get used to it.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 13
I think I will get used to it. Enjoy it while it lasts, fellas.
What’d you mean? You’re not splitting up, are you?
I’m not splitting up, are you Mark?
No, I’m not. Are you Korky?
No, I’m not. Still in one piece here.
See, we’re at the top now, but how long d’you get at the top? A year? Two years? Nobody’s ever had more than that.
But you’re better than those other groups.
People’1l move on, they always do. They’1ll find a new group with longer hair or tighter trousers.
F/X WAITER HAS COME BACK OVER WITH THEIR DRINKS, PUTS THEM ON
THE TABLE.
Your drinks, gentlemen. Miss.
Cheers.
How come you were in the crowd anyways? You're a bit older than our usual audience.
I’m a sociologist, I’m studying youth subcultures. I’m interested in why you’re so popular.
Really?
Kids like pop music. There you go, job done.
(LAUGHS) So much for sociology!
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 14
No, I think Rita's right. I think perhaps there is something different about your success.
It’s true that nobody’s ever been this big before. Not in England, anyway.
Don’t tell Cliff Richard, mind.
Maybe everyone was just ready for something to happen, and we're it. It could’ve been anyone, it happened to be us.
But you’re great.
I know we are. But we’ve been lucky, too. Back in Hamburg, a lot of good groups broke up ‘cause of national service.
National service?
We all got out of it. Flat feet, me.
Bad eyesight.
; Art student. Vital to the running of the country. Apparently.
I wish my brother had got out of it.
Why?
Training accident. He never wanted to do it in the first place.
(BEAT) Oh, love, I’m sorry. Look at us sitting here laughing about getting out of it —
I’m glad you got out of it. Nobody should have to do it, I mean what are we doing it for? So we can go off and help the Yanks in Vietnam?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 15
(TO HIMSELF) Vietnam? (ALOUD) You said a lot of good groups in Hamburg broke up.. what other groups [were there —]
Hey up, gaffer’s giving us the nod.
What’s the rush? We’ve not got a gig tonight.
He’s probably set up an interview or a photo session or a recording session or he wants us to open a supermarket.
I wonder if it would be possible [to see you again] —
Of course! Tickets. Least we can do. Look, here’s a couple for the Royal Variety, Monday night. Backstage too.
F/X JAMES HANDS OVER TWO TICKETS.
Can we talk then?
Sure.
Come on.
And thanks again!
F/X THEY LEAVE.
Wow. Thanks for letting me tag along. I don’t know how I can ever pay you back —
You can start by telling me more about your brother.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 10. INT. BUNK ROOM — 1960
F/X HAMBURG NIGHTLIFE CAN BE HEARD IN DISTANCE — MUSIC AND
REVELRY. DOOR OPENS. NYSSA AND THE COMMON MEN WALK IN.
And this is our room...
(BEAT) Oh.
It was like this when we got here. Honest. Wasn't it, Mark?
Actually it was a bit worse. We cleaned that window.
It’s fine — sorry, what was your name?
Korky. Like the cat.
What cat?
I’m sure it’s not what you’re used to, princess. But it’s all we serfs can afford.
I’m not a princess.
No, but you’re close enough that you didn’t realise that was a joke.
Stop confusing the poor lass, Mark. She’s had a shock.
Where are you from?
(BEAT) Esher.
(POSH VOICE) Oh Esher.
I should find that man. The one from the docks.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 17
So he can beat you up again?
He didn’t beat me up. But he’s dangerous and I need to know what he’s planning to do.
Should you be looking for him, if he’s dangerous?
Just want to remind you all, we’ve got a gig tonight. Now, as it happens.
I need to go, I can’t waste any time.
You also can’t wander around Hamburg this time of night on your own.
Why doesn’t she come and see the show?
Good idea. Then we can help you find that spotty herbert afterwards.
I’m not sure it’s really my thing.
If you came to see The Beatles, pet, you’re going to love us.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 18
SCENE 11. INT. AITRPORT LOUNGE — 1963
F/X DOCTOR AND RITA STILL HAVING A DRINK.
Dad didn’t tell me exactly what happened to Greg. It was something to do with... they were training with live ammunition.
It shouldn’t have happened.
No, that’s what I’m saying, he shouldn’t have had to go on service.
Yes, but more than that... this will sound very odd, Rita.
I’ve had a very odd day.
Right. (BEAT) In the version of history I know, National Service ended three years ago.
What do you mean, ‘the version you know’?
I travel in time. I’ve seen the future. Sometimes history changes — sometimes in minor ways that don’t affect the bigger picture, sometimes... it’s like this.
(BEAT) Assuming I buy all this — how does something like that happen?
Usually, because someone makes it change. Like switching points on a railway line — the train heads off in a different direction.
Why would someone want National Service to keep going?
I’m not sure. Maybe that was just a side effect of the main objective.
You're saying Greg died as a side effect?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 19
Side effects can kill, that’s why you read the label before you take medicine. What I mean is, I wonder if the real point was to take The Beatles out of their place in history.
The Beatles? That other group you were talking about?
Yes. In the world I know, they’re the ones who’ve got hundreds of fans greeting them at the airport.
So The Common Men forced loads of lads into the army so they could be the biggest pop group in Britain?
In the world, if things continue along the same course. But it may not be their doing — it’s hard to tell.
So what are you going to do about it?
You and I are going on a magical mystery tour.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 20
SCENE 12. INT. TARDIS — 1963
F/X DOORS OPEN.
Oh.
It’s my time machine.
Inside a police box.
Yes. Always feels like she’s come home when we pop back here. To the 1960s, I mean. Not to London Airport.
So... it’s all true then.
Yes. Now, you asked what I was going to do. National Service should have been abolished at the end of 1960...
So — you’re going to go back and change it? Just like that?
I doubt it’1ll be that easy, but I'll certainly try.
And that would bring Greg back?
Logically, it would stop him being in the accident, so...
Then I’1l help. Anything you need me to do.
Excellent. I was hoping you’d say that.
Until we came in here I did think you were mad, you know.
Yes, I know.
Now I’m wondering if I am.
F/X DOCTOR OPERATES THE CONTROLS. TARDIS TAKES OFF. HE KEEPS
WORKING AT THE CONTROLS DURING NEXT SPEECH.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 21
National Service was abolished in 1960, but it was wound down from 1957... so let’s look for the reasons why that didn’t happen. If we start with the Suez fallout and work from —
F/X TARDIS JUDDERS ALARMINGLY.
(TO TARDIS) Come on, old girl...
F/X SQUEAL OF PROTEST FROM TARDIS CIRCUITS.
All right, all right!
F/X DOCTOR OPERATES MORE CONTROLS, TARDIS SETTLES
What’s the problem?
Er.. normally it does travel in time. Honestly.
F/X DOCTOR OPERATES MORE CONTROLS.
But not today?
Let me see...
F/X TARDIS LANDS. DOORS OPEN. AIR RAID BEYOND.
1940. Not a problem. Interesting.
Er... are we in the middle of an air raid?
Hmm? Yes, I expect so.
DOWN.
F/X A BOMB EXPLODES OUTSIDE THE TARDIS DOOR, SCATTERING DEBRIS
— CHUNKS OF EARTH — INSIDE & ONTO RITA.
Look! You didn’t have to take me into the Blitz just to prove
this thing’s a real time machine. Can we go please?
Of course.
F/X DOCTOR CLOSES DOORS.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 22
I didn’t just do it to prove the TARDIS works, though. I needed to know whether the TARDIS had a fault... or whether someone else had intervened.
F/X TARDIS TAKES OFF.
How d’you mean?
A part of Earth's history has been time-locked.
What does that mean? You can’t go there?
Essentially. It’s complex and very, very difficult to pull off, but someone has locked off the time vortex all around that point in 1957.
To stop you doing what you just tried to do.
That seems the logical assumption, doesn’t it? Someone’s changed history, and now they’re stopping me — or anyone else — from changing it back.
So what now?
Back to 1963.
F/X DOCTOR LANDS TARDIS.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 13. INT. PFANNKUCHEN CLUB — 1960
F/X SEEDY. PUNTERS ARE CHATTING, IN GERMAN: ‘WO SIND DIE
MUSIKER?’ ‘ES IST EINE KALTE NACHT DRAUBEN’, ‘DU SIEHST TOLL
HEUTE ABEND’, ‘HEY BARKEEPER! VIER WEITERE BIERE HIER!’ (I
SUPPLY MORE IF NEEDED.) MUSIC ON JUKEBOX.
Ta dah! The Pfannkuchen Club!
Gosh. (COUGHS)
Nyssa? Can I get you a drink?
Or a gas mask?
It is very smoky.
Ah yes. The sweet smell of success, eh Mark?
(WINE CRITIC VOICE) James, I’m getting aromas of sweat and just a hint of stale beer...
I’m afraid I don’t have any money...
Don’t worry: I’1ll get it.
Don’t let Gunter see you buying drinks for girls, Korky. He’1l think he’s paying us too much.
I’d just like some water, please.
Get her a coffee. She could do with something to perk her up.
If she needs something to perk her up, boys, then the best thing we can do is get up there and play.
(TO BARMAN) Coffee and a glass of water for the lady.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 24
& MARK: (MOCKING) ‘The lady’!
Thank you.
(OFF) Come on!
F/X THE COMMON MEN BOUND ONTO THE STAGE. CHEERS, CRIES OF
‘MACH SHAU!’ OPENING BARS OF ‘WHO IS THAT MAN’.
SCENE 14. EXT. STREET — 1963
F/X IN LIVERPOOL. DOCTOR MEETS RITA.
Hi Doctor.
Rita. How did you get on?
The woman at the first house said John lives in town now. She thought I was an old girlfriend come round because I was in trouble, or something.
Did she say what he’s doing?
He’s still in a group. They’re called The Famous Five. It’s a joke name because there’s four of them.
(IN CHORUS WITH RITA) ..there’s four of them.
I asked who else was in the group, because I thought they might be your Beatles with a different name, but she said they were called Pete, Chas and another Pete.
What about the other house?
I met Paul, he was visiting his dad. He was nice. He’s a clerk at a shipping office. But yeah, he did his service.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 25

So did George. He’s back now, apprenticed to his father. Ringo didn’t get called up because of health problems — but he was never in the group in the first place. Both George and Ringo knew The Common Men from the clubs in Hamburg.
So did Paul. He said he was going to get in touch and offer them some songs. I told him they’ve got lots of good songs of their own. He said so does he.
But he’s missed his moment, and he’s lost his group. The perfect storm which created The Beatles has been quelled.
And The Common Men have stepped in.
But was it really as easy as that?
They’re a great group. Talent will out, as my mum used to say.
But can they keep it up like The Beatles did? I suppose we’1l see on Monday how good they are.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 26
SCENE 15. INT. PFANNKUCHEN CLUB — 1960
F/X LAST NOTES OF GIG BEING PLAYED. END OF ‘JUST COUNT TO
THREE’. HUGE CHEER FROM CROWD, INCLUDING NYSSA AND SADIE (LATE TEENS, CONFIDENT).
(ON MIC) Cheers, we’ve been The Common Men and we’1l continue to be so tomorrow!
F/X CROWD SETTLES DOWN TO MORE GERMAN CHATTER: ‘DAS WAR
UNGLAUBLICH!’ ‘JAMES SANG SO GUT HEUTE,’ ‘SIE MACHEN EINEN
VERSION EINES SONGS VON LITTLE RICHARD’.
Heavens.
Aren’t they great? I’ve been watching them since Liverpool, but they get better and better!
Liverpool?
They’re from Liverpool. Can’t you tell from the accent?
I’m not very good with accents.
Expect everyone north of Hertfordshire sounds the same to you.
Er.. yes. So do you know them?
No. Not properly. I’m just a fan to them.
Gosh. You must like them a lot to follow them around like this.
Best group in the world. In the universe, probably. And one day everybody’1l agree with me.
F/X THE COMMON MEN ARRIVE WITH THEM.
(APPROACHING) Nyssa! Nyssa!
(TO NYSSA; SHARPLY) You know them?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 27
We just met. Hello, Korky.
(ARRIVING) Well, what d’you think?
It was very... energetic.
Throw the poor kid a bone, love.
I liked it. I’ve just never seen anything quite like it before. Where I come from, music is far more formalised and complex.
Probably brought up on Beethoven and that, weren’t you?
Everyone else seemed to enjoy it a lot.
It was amazing.
Yeah, cheers Sadie.
It was a good night tonight. You got lucky.
Lucky nothing. Korky was trying extra hard to impress his new friend.
Give over.
I’m not knocking it, she can come and watch us every night if that’s what happens.
F/X CAMERA CLICK AND FLASH.
Hey! If you’re going to take pictures, Sadie luv, at least give me a chance to do me hair first.
sorry.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 28
SCENE 16. INT. APARTMENT — 1970
F/X AS BEFORE.

Something seemed to click around then. When we came back from Hamburg and played Liverpool again — crowds went mad. Went on tour, crowds went mad. You couldn’t hear yourself play. It got frightening sometimes. They called it Common Mania. (BEAT) When did they start saying Common Mania? Was it after the Royal Variety?
SCENE 17. INT. DRESSING ROOM — 1963
F/X AT THE PRINCE OF WALES THEATRE. MUFFLED SCREAMS OF FANS.
You’d have thought they’d have given us separate dressing rooms. Mind you, the Queen has to sit in that ashtray all evening, so I suppose we got off lightly.
Here, Mark, listen to this.
What?
F/X JAMES OPENS A WINDOW — THE SCREAM IS BOTH MORE AUDIBLE AND
FRENZIED, AS THE CROWD CAN SEE HIM AT THE WINDOW. ‘JAMES!’ ‘OH MY GOD!’ ‘JUMP, WE’LL CATCH YOU!’ ‘LOVE YOU JAMES!’
Evening girls.
F/X HE CLOSES THE WINDOW. THEN HE OPENS IT AGAIN AND THE SAME
HAPPENS.

DOCTOR: Don’t worry, Paravatar — you helped enormously. We know a great deal more than we did before.
PARAVATAR: We still don’t know why they’re here.
DOCTOR: No. But given the effort, someone must be expecting quite a reward.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 74
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 50. EXT. STREET — 1960
KORKY: Nyssa! Are you all right?
NYSSA: Yes, Korky. Don’t stop running!
KORKY: Maybe we should split up?
NYSSA: Why?
KORKY: He’s clearly after me —
NYSSA: We don’t know that. Maybe he’s after me, maybe he’s trying to protect you —
KORKY: It’s a dead end!
NYSSA: No! Quickly, if we turn back —
LENNY: Too late, guys. Sorry. Gotcha now!
KORKY: Look, I don’t know what you want but I’m just a drummer in a
LENNY: Oh, you’re a lot more than that. And she knows it.
NYSSA: Me?
LENNY: Yeah, you. And I’m gonna find out who you are and what your game is, and then... I’m gonna kill you.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 75

elements.text: PART THREE
GRAMS DR WHO THEME
SCENE 51. EXT. STREET — 1960
F/X THEY TURN A CORNER AND STOP.
It’s a dead end!
No! Quickly, if we turn back —
Too late, guys.
Sorry. Gotcha now!
Look, I don’t know what you want but I’m just a drummer in a —
Oh, you’re a lot more than that. And she knows it.
Me?
Yeah, you. And I’m gonna find out who you are and what your game is, and then... I’m gonna kill you.
So what have we got to lose then?
Shut up and move.
You don’t want to shoot us or you’d have done it by now.
Korky —
It ain’t that important to me.
I wanna know what she’s told you
and where she came from, but in the final analysis —
(CALLS) Mark!
Where?
James!
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 76
Oh, trick of the light.
F/X WITH AN EFFORT, KORKY KNOCKS OVER SOME DUSTBINS, TOPPLING
OVER. LENNY DROPS THE GUN.
Agh!
Korky!
He’s dropped the gun — grab it!
No you don’t —
F/X NYSSA AND LENNY BOTH LUNGE FOR IT — IT SPINS AWAY DOWN THE
ALLEY.
Where did it go?
Somewhere in the shadows.
Leave it — let’s run!
F/X THEY ESCAPE. LENNY IS LEFT SCRABBLING FOR THE GUN.
Dammit! Where is it...?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 77
SCENE 52. INT. APARTMENT — 1970
F/X AS BEFORE.
People blame Lenny for breaking the band up. We’d have broken up a lot sooner without him. We’d been together nine years. You’re not married, are you, Rita?
No, Mark, I told you that.
You've probably never spent nine years with anyone then.
My family.
There you go. And do you get on with your family?
I didn’t for a while. They didn’t get me — still don’t, really. But then my brother died...
Oh yeah. I remember. Sorry.
It’s all right. Go on.
(BEAT) Forgot where I was.
Nine years.

That’s right. And it’s been three more since then, so that’s twelve years with just the three of us, in each other’s pockets. The only people you can really talk to because nobody else knows what it’s like and you can’t trust hardly anyone else anyway, they only want a piece of you.
Wasn’t that true of Lenny too?
But he never pretended he was anything else. Not like all the others, like Paravatar, like the Doctor.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 78
The Doctor? What makes you say that?
He’s tried to get in touch loads of times since then, come up to us in clubs, outside the studio — don’t listen to him any more. He wants something.
I thought he seemed nice.
So? You seem nice too. Probably are. But you still came here for something.
Yes, an interview.
There you go.
You obviously want to talk to me as well though.
Why d’you say that?
Because you’ve been talking to me for six days.
(BEAT) Has it really been six? Lost track of time.
So when Lenny became your manager, the first thing he did was send [you out —]

We shouldn’t have done that tour. But we’d cleared those months to go to Paravatar’s retreat, and then we had the time free... the others talked me into it. But the stuff we were doing then needed cellos and violas and all that faff and I said we’re not having that, we’re a [rock’n’roll band —]
F/X JUST BEFORE THE END OF MARK’S SPEECH, TAPE REEL RUNS OFF
MACHINE.
Wait — I’m out of tape.
Again?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 79
F/X RITA RUMMAGES IN A BAG.
And that was my last reel.
You should’ve brought more.
I brought about twenty, I didn’t think I’d need more. I’1l have to go and get some.
Don’t be long.
Worried you’1ll get lonely?
No, not lonely... just bored. The wife’s never around any more —
You don’t have a wife any more.
She’1l come back. She wouldn’t give this up.
(BEAT) I won’t be long.
Put the needle on the record before you go.
OK.
F/X RITA DOES SO, THEN LEAVES. MUSIC COMES FROM THE RECORD
— THE SONG FROM THE ROYAL VARIETY: ‘OH WON’T YOU PLEASE
ME’
Good tune, this. One of mine.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 80
SCENE 53. EXT. DOCKS — 1960
F/X NYSSA AND KORKY RUNNING. NOT MANY PEOPLE HERE, BUT SOUNDS
OF SHIPPING IN DISTANCE. THEY COME TO A HALT.
(PANTING) Korky? Where are we now?
(PANTING) The docks. Maybe we should’ve stayed in a busier place —
No. We don’t want innocent people getting hurt.
But maybe he wouldn’t want to risk it. He doesn’t want the rozzers on his case —
Rozzers?
Police.
The police don’t matter to him. He can get away from here ina second. (STARTS TO MOVE OFF AGAIN) Come on.
(JOGGING) We can’t just keep running.
(JOGGING) We need to get his time machine from him somehow.
I like your ‘somehow’ there. We should’ve got his zap gun, then we could’ve said give the time machine to us or we’ll kill you.
If we could’ve worked out how to use the gun. And what if he’d said no? (THEY STOP) Would we have killed him?
We could’ve shot him in the leg.
We need to find another way. You don’t know who he is?
No idea. He’s American, isn’t he?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 81
He seems to be.
Always wanted to go to America.
SCENE 54. EXT. STREET — 1970
F/X A STREET IN NEW YORK. RITA IS WALKING ALONG.
(OFF) Rita? Rita!
What...?
F/X DOCTOR HURRIES OVER TO HER AND FALLS INTO STEP.
How’ve you been?
Doctor! What are you doing here?
I was going to ask you the same thing.
I bet you’ve come to see Mark.
Yes.
He doesn’t want to see you.
He mentioned me?

He seemed confused. First he said he hadn’t met you since London Airport, 1963. Then he said he met you in 1967, but hadn’t seen you since. Then he said you’ve tried to contact him and approach him loads of times.
Yes. The timeline’s changing.
Again?
Yes. But not enough.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 8&2
Why'd he turn against you?
I don’t know. When we met in 1967, we seemed to be getting on well. But since then, they’ve been giving me the cold shoulder. All of them.
He’s changed, that’s for sure. He always had that negative streak, but now... he just seems bitter, and angry.
So are you and he...?
No.
It’s just, I saw you coming out of his building —
I’m interviewing him. I’m a journalist now.
Gosh.

I told you I’d keep finding out more. Eventually people started to ask why I was doing it, and I didn’t want it to seem weird, so I said it was for an article. And then I wrote the article, and it got published.
Well done.
It was about how National Service was crippling the British youth scene. I interviewed Paul for it.
They’ve got rid of it now, but too little, too late.
You said you’d come back.
Yes. Sorry. Been busy. Did you want to ask me something?
Yes. Where can you buy sound tapes in New York?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 8&3
SCENE 55. INT. AIRPORT — 1970
F/X PASSENGERS MOVING THROUGH ARRIVAL GATE, INCLUDING JAMES
AND LENNY. WE ARE IN NEW YORK.
Passport please, sir.
You need to see this guy’s passport? Really?
Pipe down, Len, it’s fine.
This is James O’Meara, you know. The one and only.
(TO OFFICER) Ignore him. Here.
Thank you sir, enjoy your visit to New York.
I’ve got a feeling I won’t, but thanks.
F/X JAMES AND LENNY MOVE ONWARDS.
It’s gonna be great. We’re gonna begin a whole new phase of The Common Men.
Fiver says I don’t even get to see his face. He’1ll shut himself in and wait for us to go away.
Then we won’t go away. He’s gotta come out eventually.
You can stay indoors as long as you like if you’re rich enough, Lenny.
I know you, James. If you don’t give it your best shot you’1ll regret it the rest of your life.
(BEAT) Let’s get it done and we can be home for tea.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 84
SCENE 56. INT. DEPARTMENT STORE — 1970
F/X DOCTOR AND RITA QUEUEING UP.
Rita, have you met their new manager?
Met him, been chatted up by him, been sued by him.
Sued?
He threatened to, anyway. Wanted me to hand over some photos he didn’t like the look of. (TO SHOP ASSISTANT) Just those, please.
Sure.
F/X PURCHASE RUNG UP ON TILL.
I haven’t been able to get near the group since he took over. Remember those hordes of screaming fans who nearly tore us to pieces —
— at the Royal Variety? Of course. (TO SHOP ASSISTANT) Thanks.
F/X RITA AND THE DOCTOR WALK AWAY.
They’re always around now.

The group split up and the fans still won’t leave them alone. There’s half a dozen outside Mark’s apartment any time of the day or night, hoping they’1ll see him pop out for milk. That reminds me, I need to pick up some milk.
You’re running errands for him?
He won’t go outside. He seems afraid of something.
He may be right to be.
Why?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 85
I think Lenny’s trying to use them.
Well, yeah. He’s a rock manager.
More than that. That’s why I came here, I hoped I might be able to get close to Mark without Lenny getting in the way.
So you want me to take you up to his place?
SCENE 57. EXT. DOCKS — 1960
F/X NYSSA AND KORKY HIDING, TRYING TO STAY QUIET WHILE
THEIR BREATH. FOOTSTEPS ON DOCK, A SHORT DISTANCE AWAY. A BOAT’S ENGINE OBSCURES THEIR VOICES.
(LOW) Korky! Here he comes.
(LOW) OK, I’1l grab his gun.
(LOW) I’1l1 grab his gun.
(LOW) Nys, come on —
(LOW) I’ve done this sort of thing a lot more times than you have.
(LOW) Fine, but I’1l run to distract him.
(LOW) All right. (BEAT) Now. Go!
F/X KORKY RUNS.
Stop! Korky! I don’t want to hurt you —
F/X LENNY LETS OFF A COUPLE OF LASER ZAPS. THEN NYSSA BARRELS
INTO HIM.
Oof!
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 86
(GRUNT OF EFFORT AS SHE GETS THE GUN OFF HIM) Got it!
Nice one!
OK, OK — get off me.
Now. I want to know who you are, where you got a time from and what you’re —
F/X SADIE, SNEAKING UP, JUMPS ON KORKY.
Argh!
Drop the gun or I’11 cut his throat!
F/X NYSSA DROPS THE GUN.
Thanks, Sadie.
Sadie? What’re you doing?
I thought you loved him?
And I know what’s best for him. Don’t I?
Careful with the knife —
Don’t I?
Whatever you say, doll —
All right. Here. (DROPS THE GUN)
Thanks. (PICKS IT UP) Let’s all go somewhere a little cosy, yeah?
machine
more
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 87
SCENE 58. INT. APARTMENT — 1970
F/X MARK IS STILL LISTENING TO THE RECORD — THE END OF ‘JUST
COUNT TO THREE’ PLAYS, THEN THE CRACKLE OF THE NEEDLE, THEN IT
OFF & THE RECORD STOPS PLAYING. QUIET. MARK IS LOOKING
PIECES OF PAPER AND PHOTOGRAPHS. RITA ENTERS.
Mark? I got milk, eggs and bread.
Fried egg sarnies then. Champion, Rita.
Where did you get all those photos?
Someone left them in a box outside the door. There’s magazines, too, and tapes of old radio interviews.
Quite a collection to just abandon on someone’s doorstep.
What’s he doing here?
I bumped into him on the street.
I told you, he’s bad news.
What do you think I’m trying to do?
Lenny said you... he said... Can’t remember what he said.
Doctor, you’re going to mess this up for me.
Do you trust Lenny?
Doesn’t Lenny just want you to carry on with the group, no matter what?
I'm not going back. I’ve had it with all that.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 88
You’re looking at all these old photographs, though.
That’s not me in those pictures any more. It’s not us.
Mark... I just want to talk.
Talk? I can talk all day.
You can say that again. Doctor, can you put the milk and eggs in the fridge?
Where’s the kitchen?
Just a fridge and a cooker, over there in the corner.
Ah.
F/X DOCTOR GOES TO PUT THE STUFF AWAY.
Mark, it’s all good material this, but I think six days of tape is more than enough to fill four pages in Disc & Music Echo.
It’s not going to be an interview. It’s going to be a book.
A book?
You’re going to write a book about how it really was.
Don’t I get a say in this?
Don’t you want to?
Well... yeah.
There you go then. People need to know how it really was.
F/X DOCTOR RETURNS.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 89
Why?
People are still obsessed with us. They need to know the truth. See us with our trousers down. Then maybe they’1ll stop.
SCENE 59. INT. TAXI — 1970
F/X DRIVING THROUGH THE CITY.
Do you miss it, Lenny?
Miss what?
New York.
Oh yeah, yeah. Like crazy. Brooklyn Bridge, Central Park, yellow cabs — I ache for them. You know James, if he comes back we can still get a new single out for Christmas.
Christmas is in a month.
This is 1970. You can make a record in a week these days.
I don’t want to put pressure on him.
And I checked venues, you could do three shows in London, New York, Los Angeles —
What’s all the rush?
Rush? I’1ll1 tell you the rush — you won’t be young forever, and you won’t be on top of the world forever. And you gotta make the most of it while it’s still there.
I dunno. I mean, is there anything left for us to do?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 90
Oh yeah.
But we’ve conquered the world. Where else is there to go?
LAUGHS
What’s funny?
Nothing.
SCENE 60. INT. APARTMENT — 1970
F/X MARK IS STILL GOING OVER OLD PHOTOS.
Mark? Where’s this one?
Toyko, ‘66. And that’s Bahamas, '65.. Adelaide '64! You never saw anything like that. It’s all so... maybe I shouldn’t have gone...
Everyone wants you to get the group back together.
Korky doesn’t.
Oh?
He’s had it. Don’t blame him, putting up with James and me. Says he wants to be an actor.
Children’s television?
I said that. He’d be great at that.
F/X MARK RUMMAGES MORE THROUGH THE BOX.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 91
Oh man, look — this is the interview.
I saw this when it was in the Standard. We just laughed when we read it in the office.
Yanks didn’t like it. Not at all. What’s the diagnosis, Doc?
F/X HE CHUCKS THE MAGAZINE AT THE DOCTOR.

(READING) ‘Kids don’t go to church any more to feel part of something bigger, they come to our gigs. They listen to us when they want to know what’s what. I’m not saying they should but they do. It’s like we’re the new gods. We’ve got power over these kids because they listen to us and talk about us.’
I didn’t say it to be big-headed, I just meant that’s how other people see us. But it came out a bit wrong, or it was taken wrong.
Rita.. I’m going to make some tea, could you help me please?
Right.
F/X DOCTOR AND RITA HEAD FOR THE STOVE.
(OFF) Three sugars.
Yes, I know.
F/X DOCTOR FILLS KETTLE, PUTS IT ON, TALKS COVERTLY.
(LOW) What is it?
(LOW) Something about that interview. Where are the matches?
(LOW) Here.
(LOW) Thank you.
F/X DOCTOR LIGHTS A MATCH FOR THE STOVE.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 92
(LOW) What about the interview? That was years ago.
(LOW) There’s something about the power of the group, the three of them together. If they split up, they’1ll never match what they were as a unit — creatively or in terms of popularity.
(LOW) Of course not, that’s why Lenny wants to get them back together.
(LOW) They’re amplifying each others’ impact — but if they’ve split up.. there’s something more. This isn’t finished yet.
(LOW) What do we do?
(LOW) Don’t encourage him to get the band back together.
(LOW) But that’s my story — our readers want the group to get back together.
(LOW) Please, just go along with this.
(LOW) All right.
F/X DOCTOR FINISHES MAKING THE TEA AND THEY RETURN TO MARK.
There you go.
Cheers. These go right back — look at that one.
Good grief.
What is it?
Hamburg. A fan took this at the club. Can’t remember who that girl is, but Korky certainly took a shine to her — just look at his face!
Nyssa.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 93
What?
That must be where she went after she vanished at the airport.
Nyssa! That’s right. Nice lass. Shy, but sweet.
What happened to her?
Er... I don’t remember.
Please, Mark. This is important!
Mate, I don’t remember. She just hung around the club for a night or two, she stayed in our room.. then she vanished. Korky never mentioned her again.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 94
SCENE 61. INT. CELLAR — 1960
F/X NYSSA AND KORKY ARE BEING TIED TO CHAIRS BY SADIE.
Nice and tight, Sadie.
I can manage to tie a knot, Len.
Why are you helping him?
Cos I want to.
You might think that, but he could be controlling your mind and you [wouldn’t even —]
He’s not controlling anything. I’m here because I love them.
Yeah, seems like it.
Oh, you don’t know what Lenny’s got planned yet.
Don’t tell him.
I wasn’t going to tell him. (TO KORKY) He found me at a gig.
That doesn’t narrow it down. You came to them all, even when we were useless.
You’ve always been great, and it made me angry when the other groups slagged you off. Then Lenny told me what he was going to do. He’s going to make you big.
Don’t tell him!
I’m not telling him the main bit.
What are you getting out of it?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 95
I’m their number one fan. He’s seen the future. I’m going to follow them around the world and see everything they do, and Lenny’s going to pay for it.
Yes, I experienced his time-travel equipment first hand. Rather primitive, I thought.
It does what I need it to do. What are you doing here?
Trying to get her nasty little claws into Korky.
You must have a very short memory. I’m here because I got caught up in your time-travel equipment.
I don’t mean here as in Hamburg, I mean here as in Earth.
Oh. I’m... visiting.
C’mon, gimme some credit. You’ve gotta be a Jude.
A jude?
An Adjudicator, a Jude. The cops, if you like.
If you’re afraid I’m the police, you must be doing something illegal.
What, other than shooting at us?
Something much worse than that. Something that’s illegal on his world, something they’d pursue him all the way here for.
Something to do with me? With the band? Is he from my world?
So, she told you you’re not human, did she?
That’s what she said.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 96
It doesn’t make any difference to me.
Cool it, sister.
Yes, Korky: you’re from the same place as him. So are Mark and James. Did you bring them here, Lenny? Insert them into Earth’s history?
I’m gonna make these boys great.
They’re already great.
Greater than great. And you, young lady... are not gonna stop me. (TO SADIE) OK, wipe his memory.
What?
Sorry, can’t have you remembering any of this. You’ve gotta fit in here, and that means you can’t know what you really are... just yet, anyway.
Hold still.
No!
You can’t do this to him!
Of course I can. He’s mine.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 97
SCENE 62. INT. APARTMENT — 1970
F/X DOCTOR LOOKING THROUGH MORE PHOTOGRAPHS.
Mark, is this the only picture of her? Of Nyssa?
Like I say, she was only there one or two nights. Oh, that’s a great pic — Abbey Road, '66.. or could be '’67...
And he never mentioned her again?
Not that I remember. Funny, cos Korks seemed smitten with her...
Logically... that could be because I went back, or will go back, and pick her up.
Go back?
He’s a time traveller.
F/X MARK KEEPS LOOKING THROUGH THE PHOTOS.
(LAUGHS) Sure. Blackpool Big Night Out, ‘65. Shea Stadium, '65...
That must be it. You found her, and maybe Korky saw you take her away in the TARDIS, and he never said anything because he didn’t think the others would believe it.
Yes. Unless... I don’t get back there and save her. And something else gets her.
Cavern, ‘61... Amsterdam, ' 64...
Then you have to go and find her. Now. Before something else does.
Believe me, I want to, but it won’t make any difference. That’s the nature of time travel. Before I go, I need to [ensure that
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 98
F/X MARK’S VOICE HAS BECOME DISTORTED, LOWER. DOCTOR AND RITA
NOTICE.
Morecambe '62.. Stockholm '63...
Doctor... what’s wrong with him?
London ‘65.. London '’67...
Mark...? Are you all right?
Give me the photograph.
But it’s the only one of Nyssa —
I need it!
Why?
I need all of them!
F/X ENERGY CRACKLE.
Ahh!
F/X DOCTOR KNOCKED BACKWARDS, HITS THE COOKER.
Oof!
Doctor!
F/X RITA DASHES OVER TO HIS SIDE.
I’m all right. Just hit my head on the cooker.
He knocked you halfway across the room.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 99
Pictures... from here to there, from then to now... a web running through the years and across the world...
He doesn’t even sound like himself.
Something’s taking him over... or something that’s been submerged is breaking through...
New strength!
F/X DOZENS OF ENERGY CRACKLES, AND A RISING HUM.
He’s drawing energy from the photographs.
How?
Just as he said, the images form a web, recording moments in his life. But where’s the power coming from?
What do you mean?
Energy has to come from somewhere. He’s using the photos to access it, but...
(SICKLY) He seems like he’s... growing...
Rita? Are you all right?
I don’t feel... quite...
Millions upon millions upon millions of people, every day seeing my face, hearing my voice, reading about me, writing about me, talking about me, thinking about me...
No. No! Stop!
What is it?
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 100
That’s where the energy is coming from — the people who’ve seen these images. His fans. That was the point all along — to make him famous. All three of them.
What’s going to happen to me?
(TO MARK) Mark. Can’t you hear me? Stop this now!
Doctor?
F/X MARK IS MUTATING MORE AND MORE, AND GETTING LARGER: HIS
IS LOUDER, DEEPER.
It cannot be stopped!
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 1/01
SCENE 63. EXT. STREET — 1970
F/X OUTSIDE MARK’S APARTMENT BUILDING. JAMES AND LENNY GET OUT
OF A TAXI. A SHORT DISTANCE AWAY, SOME CAMPED-OUT FANS NOTICE
‘IT CAN’T BE,’ ‘YEAH — IT’S JAMES!’ ‘WHY’S HE HERE?’
Keep the change.
F/X TAXI DRIVES AWAY.
Lenny, look — he’s still got the fans camping outside.
He’1ll still have the fans camping outside when he’s sixty-four, James. And so will you.
Will the fans be sixty-four too?
F/X JAMES ENTERS THE BUILDING.
Evening, ladies — or is it afternoon?
Gimme a minute, I’m gonna talk to them.
(OFF) OK.
(TO SADIE) Sadie! How’s it going?
I left the box of stuff outside the apartment. Don’t know if he took it in.
Couldn’t you put it in his hands?
He’s not answering the door. To anybody.
This better work. We’re so close...
You've been saying that since 1964.
FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 102
I know, but these last few years with me in control... it’s all been so tight. Nothing bad’s getting out — even when they split, I kept a lid on it all. It’s gotta happen soon.
SCENE 64. INT. CELLAR — 1960
F/X LENNY AND SADIE OPERATING SOME EQUIPMENT.
The Doctor won’t let you do this.
Doctor?
He knows something’s wrong. He’s onto you, and he’1l put it right.
He the guy who told the boys to duck down at the airport?
Yes.
He did me a favour. (TO SADIE) OK, this is done.
How do you know you’ve erased the right bits of his memory?
I wiped a good chunk of it just to be sure... anything else, we put down to drink.

LENNY: So, she told you you’re not human, did she?
KORKY: That’s what she said.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 96
SADIE: It doesn’t make any difference to me.
LENNY: Cool it, sister.
NYSSA: Yes, Korky: you’re from the same place as him. So are Mark and James. Did you bring them here, Lenny? Insert them into Earth’s history?
LENNY: I’m gonna make these boys great.
SADIE: They’re already great.
LENNY: Greater than great. And you, young lady... are not gonna stop me. (TO SADIE) OK, wipe his memory.
KORKY: What?
LENNY: Sorry, can’t have you remembering any of this. You’ve gotta fit in here, and that means you can’t know what you really are... just yet, anyway.
SADIE: Hold still.
KORKY: No!
NYSSA: You can’t do this to him!
LENNY: Of course I can. He’s mine.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 97
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 62. INT. APARTMENT — 1970
DOCTOR: Mark, is this the only picture of her? Of Nyssa?
MARK: Like I say, she was only there one or two nights. Oh, that’s a great pic — Abbey Road, '66.. or could be '’67...
RITA: And he never mentioned her again?
MARK: Not that I remember. Funny, cos Korks seemed smitten with her...
DOCTOR: Logically... that could be because I went back, or will go back, and pick her up.
MARK: Go back?
RITA: He’s a time traveller.
MARK: (LAUGHS) Sure. Blackpool Big Night Out, ‘65. Shea Stadium, '65...
RITA: That must be it. You found her, and maybe Korky saw you take her away in the TARDIS, and he never said anything because he didn’t think the others would believe it.
DOCTOR: Yes. Unless... I don’t get back there and save her. And something else gets her.
MARK: Cavern, ‘61... Amsterdam, ' 64...
RITA: Then you have to go and find her. Now. Before something else does.
DOCTOR: Believe me, I want to, but it won’t make any difference. That’s the nature of time travel. Before I go, I need to [ensure that
DOCTOR: —]
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 98
BOTH: NOTICE.
MARK: Morecambe '62.. Stockholm '63...
RITA: Doctor... what’s wrong with him?
MARK: London ‘65.. London '’67...
DOCTOR: Mark...? Are you all right?
MARK: Give me the photograph.
DOCTOR: But it’s the only one of Nyssa —
MARK: I need it!
DOCTOR: Why?
MARK: I need all of them!
DOCTOR: Ahh!
DOCTOR: Oof!
RITA: Doctor!
DOCTOR: I’m all right. Just hit my head on the cooker.
RITA: He knocked you halfway across the room.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 99
MARK: Pictures... from here to there, from then to now... a web running through the years and across the world...
RITA: He doesn’t even sound like himself.
DOCTOR: Something’s taking him over... or something that’s been submerged is breaking through...
MARK: New strength!
DOCTOR: He’s drawing energy from the photographs.
RITA: How?
DOCTOR: Just as he said, the images form a web, recording moments in his life. But where’s the power coming from?
RITA: What do you mean?
DOCTOR: Energy has to come from somewhere. He’s using the photos to access it, but...
RITA: (SICKLY) He seems like he’s... growing...
DOCTOR: Rita? Are you all right?
RITA: I don’t feel... quite...
MARK: Millions upon millions upon millions of people, every day seeing my face, hearing my voice, reading about me, writing about me, talking about me, thinking about me...
DOCTOR: No. No! Stop!
RITA: What is it?
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 100
DOCTOR: That’s where the energy is coming from — the people who’ve seen these images. His fans. That was the point all along — to make him famous. All three of them.
RITA: What’s going to happen to me?
DOCTOR: (TO MARK) Mark. Can’t you hear me? Stop this now!
RITA: Doctor?
VOICE: IS LOUDER, DEEPER.
MARK: It cannot be stopped!
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 1/01
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 63. EXT. STREET — 1970
DOCTOR WHO: OF A TAXI. A SHORT DISTANCE AWAY, SOME CAMPED-OUT FANS NOTICE
HIM AND MURMUR: ‘IT CAN’T BE,’ ‘YEAH — IT’S JAMES!’ ‘WHY’S HE HERE?’
LENNY: Keep the change.
JAMES: Lenny, look — he’s still got the fans camping outside.
LENNY: He’1ll still have the fans camping outside when he’s sixty-four, James. And so will you.
JAMES: Will the fans be sixty-four too?
JAMES: Evening, ladies — or is it afternoon?
LENNY: Gimme a minute, I’m gonna talk to them.
JAMES: (OFF) OK.
LENNY: (TO SADIE) Sadie! How’s it going?
SADIE: I left the box of stuff outside the apartment. Don’t know if he took it in.
LENNY: Couldn’t you put it in his hands?
SADIE: He’s not answering the door. To anybody.
LENNY: This better work. We’re so close...
SADIE: You've been saying that since 1964.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 102
LENNY: I know, but these last few years with me in control... it’s all been so tight. Nothing bad’s getting out — even when they split, I kept a lid on it all. It’s gotta happen soon.
LENNY: SCENE 64. INT. CELLAR — 1960
NYSSA: The Doctor won’t let you do this.
LENNY: Doctor?
NYSSA: He knows something’s wrong. He’s onto you, and he’1l put it right.
LENNY: He the guy who told the boys to duck down at the airport?
NYSSA: Yes.
LENNY: He did me a favour. (TO SADIE) OK, this is done.
SADIE: How do you know you’ve erased the right bits of his memory?
LENNY: I wiped a good chunk of it just to be sure... anything else, we put down to drink.
NYSSA: Why did you shoot at the band?
LENNY: It got headlines. People took the boys more seriously, wanted to protect them more. Less than a month later, they shot the President and people were saying maybe it was the same guy who shot at The Common Men. That broke America for us.
NYSSA: You’ve been hopping about in time, manipulating things all along. Sooner or later you’1ll tie yourself in a knot.
LENNY: Even if I do.. you won’t be there to take advantage.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 103
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 65. INT. APARTMENT — 1970
DOCTOR WHO: ANIMAL, BUT IT IS HYSTERICAL.
MARK: I remember. I remember everything...
RITA: Doctor, I can’t... I can’t see.
DOCTOR: Don’t worry, Rita, it’s all right. I’1ll find a way, I'll reverse his power.
RITA: What’s happening?
DOCTOR: You don’t want to know. But he’s between us and the door — just hang on, if I can get you to the TARDIS I’m sure I can... do something for you.
MARK: She is tied to me by her words... I will take all of her.
DOCTOR: Why are you doing this?
MARK: Wouldn’t you, if you could?
DOCTOR: No!
MARK: Feeble.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 104
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 66. INT. STAIRWELL — 1970
JAMES: Leave the talking to me, Lenny.
LENNY: Whatever you say, James.
JAMES: In fact, perhaps you should stay out here.
LENNY: Why?
JAMES: You can be a bit abrasive.
LENNY: So can he.
JAMES: Yeah, but he’s Mark Carville and you’re not, so he gets away WEth: 2b).
LENNY: I’ll be quiet, I’1ll be low-key, I’11 give the situation whatever it needs.
JAMES: OK.
JAMES: DOOR.
JAMES: He’d better be in, after all —
LENNY: Shh — listen.
JAMES: (BEAT) What is that?
LENNY: We gotta get in there.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 105
JAMES: What’s going on?
LENNY: Something big. But why now...?
JAMES: You know, don’t you? What’s going on?
LENNY: Ah, nuts to this.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 106
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 67. INT. APARTMENT — 1970
JAMES: What the —
LENNY: It’s Mark.
JAMES: What?
MARK: You!
DOCTOR: James, be careful!
JAMES: That’s Mark?
MARK: You came here to take from me again, like you always do.
JAMES: No! I didn’t want to come at all, he made me — Lenny!
LENNY: I’1ll handle this — James, maybe you should go [and I'll —-]
MARK: No! He stays.
LENNY: Mark, this is good. It’s what I’ve always wanted for you — but I wanted it for all three of you.
JAMES: You wanted this?
DOCTOR: What is he?
LENNY: Do you remember now? Home?
MARK: Yes.. I forgot, for a long time. But now I remember.
LENNY: All our people can become this powerful, if we get the adulation of the masses.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 107
DOCTOR: All you need is love?
LENNY: But the people in charge, they don’t like us doing it. They say is changes us, gives us a thirst for more power, domination — but this is our true nature. That’s what they’re denying. That’s why they banned photographs, anything that records...
DOCTOR: So you came here.
LENNY: We’re dopes. We ought to be using our power. We can travel in time, manipulate the vortex — but we never even leave our own planet.
DOCTOR: And so you’re turning this planet into a giant battery to power your monsters.
JAMES: By making us famous?
DOCTOR: Yes. (TO LENNY) But you made them famous, instead of yourself. You stay in the background. Why?
LENNY: I’m an orchestrator. My place is behind the scenes.
DOCTOR: Mark, he’s afraid of this power. He wants you to wield it for him, he wants to control you!
MARK: I don’t take orders from no-one. Not Lenny, not James. Never again.
JAMES: I never gave you orders.
RITA: D... Doctor...?
DOCTOR: Hold on, Rita, hold on.
MARK: ; You gave everyone orders.
JAMES: Someone had to, man. It wasn’t holding together on its own.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 108
MARK: Nine hours I spent recording a guitar solo. Nine hours. You listened to every take and told me we’d almost got it right.
JAMES: Mate —
MARK: And then you came in early the next day and did it yourself in twenty minutes.
JAMES: I just did what was for the good of the group. More than you ever did.
MARK: What?
JAMES: When Korky wrote a song, you never even came in to work on it with us. You never helped him.
MARK: Don’t bring him into this.
JAMES: Why am I asking you to come back to the group? You only ever think of yourself anyway.
LENNY: No!
LENNY: What the hell did you just do?
DOCTOR: Killed him. And he used the last of Rita’s strength to do it. She’s dead.
LENNY: No! I needed all three. The Triumvirate — that’s how it worked in the old days. Three of you linked, working together would’ve been unstoppable. You weren’t meant to do this!
MARK: I’1l do what I like.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 109
LENNY: No! I did this to you.
MARK: And you can take it away?
LENNY: I can. Absolutely I can. You need the people of this world, if they turn against [you —]
MARK: Then I should destroy you too.
LENNY: Woah, woah —
MARK: So long, and thanks for all the cash.
LENNY: Sorry, Doctor, but —
MARK: So now it’s just the two of us.
DOCTOR: Mark, listen. You don’t want to destroy me —
MARK: I do though.
DOCTOR: No, I can help —
MARK: I don’t want to be helped. I just want to burn everything that refuses to be mine.
DOCTOR: Mark, please!
MARK: And I’m going to start with you.
DOCTOR WHO: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON MEN by Eddie Robson (FINAL) Page 1/10

F/X DOCTOR AND NYSSA STRIDING DOWN THE STREET IN HAMBURG.

I know.
You know?

Oh. I see. Well, they derive power from being known of. The more people who meet them, who see pictures of them, who hear their voices, who read about them — that all creates a web which enables them to draw energy from those people.
So their power comes from being famous.

Exactly. So they travelled here and found the most famous people they could — people whose music and image has been replicated around the globe. The fact they write and perform the music themselves strengthens the effect — the whole package is bound up with their personalities. It wouldn’t work as well with, say, Elvis.
